topic_name: System of Particles and Rotational Motion

canonical_explanation.text: The centre of mass (COM) of a system is the point where the entire mass can be considered concentrated. For discrete particles: x_cm = Σmᵢxᵢ/Σmᵢ. For continuous bodies, use integration. The COM of a uniform body lies at the geometric centre. Torque (τ) is the rotational analogue of force: τ = r × F, with magnitude τ = rF sin θ. Angular momentum L = r × p = Iω. Newton's second law for rotation: τ = Iα = dL/dt. The moment of inertia I = Σmᵢrᵢ² measures resistance to angular acceleration. For common bodies: solid sphere I = 2MR²/5, hollow sphere I = 2MR²/3, solid cylinder I = MR²/2, ring I = MR², rod about centre I = ML²/12, rod about end I = ML²/3. The radius of gyration k satisfies I = Mk². The parallel axis theorem: I = I_cm + Md², where d is the distance from the COM axis. The perpendicular axis theorem (for planar bodies): I_z = I_x + I_y. Rolling motion combines translation and rotation. For pure rolling, v_cm = Rω and the contact point has zero velocity. KE of rolling = ½mv² + ½Iω² = ½mv²(1 + k²/R²). On an incline, a rolling body has acceleration a = g sin θ/(1 + k²/R²). Conservation of angular momentum: if τ_ext = 0, L = Iω = constant.
rules: Centre of mass: x_cm = Σmᵢxᵢ / Σmᵢ.
Torque: τ = r × F; |τ| = rF sin θ.
Angular momentum: L = Iω; τ = dL/dt.
Moment of inertia: I = Σmᵢrᵢ²; I = Mk².
Parallel axis theorem: I = I_cm + Md².
Perpendicular axis theorem (planar): I_z = I_x + I_y.
Common I values: ring MR², disc MR²/2, solid sphere 2MR²/5, hollow sphere 2MR²/3.
Rolling condition: v = Rω; KE = ½mv²(1 + k²/R²).
Rolling on incline: a = g sin θ/(1 + k²/R²).
Conservation of angular momentum: L = Iω = constant (if τ_ext = 0).

questions.question_text: The centre of mass of a uniform rod lies at:
questions.explanation_correct: For a uniform rod, the mass is distributed symmetrically, so the COM is at the midpoint.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A uniform body's COM lies at its geometric centre due to symmetry.

questions.question_text: Two particles of masses 1 kg and 3 kg are placed at x = 0 and x = 4 m. The centre of mass is at:
questions.explanation_incorrect: x_cm = Σmᵢxᵢ/Σmᵢ = (0 + 12)/4 = 3 m. COM is closer to the heavier mass.

questions.question_text: The centre of mass of a uniform circular disc lies at:
questions.explanation_correct: A uniform circular disc has axial symmetry, so its COM is at the geometric centre.
questions.explanation_incorrect: By symmetry, the COM of any uniform symmetric body is at the geometric centre.

questions.question_text: Three particles of equal mass are placed at the vertices of an equilateral triangle of side a. The COM is at:
questions.explanation_correct: For equal masses at vertices of a triangle, the COM is at the centroid (intersection of medians).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Equal masses → COM is at the geometric centre of the configuration, i.e., the centroid.

questions.question_text: Two particles of masses 2 kg and 3 kg are at (1, 2) and (4, 6) m. The x-coordinate of COM is:
A circular disc of radius R has a circular hole of radius R/2 cut from it touching the edge. The COM shifts from the original centre by:
questions.explanation_correct: Mass of full disc ∝ R². Mass of hole ∝ (R/2)² = R²/4. Remaining mass ∝ 3R²/4. Hole centre at R/2 from centre. Shift = (R²/4 × R/2)/(3R²/4) = R/6 (opposite to hole).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Treat the hole as negative mass. Shift = m_hole × d/(m_disc − m_hole) = (M/4)(R/2)/(3M/4) = R/6.

questions.question_text: The COM of a uniform semicircular wire of radius R from the centre is:
questions.explanation_correct: For a semicircular wire, y_cm = 2R/π from the centre along the axis of symmetry.
questions.explanation_incorrect: By integration, y_cm = 2R/π for a semicircular wire. For a semicircular disc, it's 4R/(3π).

questions.question_text: If no external force acts on a system, its centre of mass:

options.text: Moves with constant velocity (or remains at rest)

questions.explanation_correct: F_ext = Ma_cm. If F_ext = 0, a_cm = 0, so COM moves with constant velocity or stays at rest.
questions.explanation_incorrect: With no external force, the COM velocity doesn't change — it moves uniformly or remains stationary.

questions.question_text: Particles of masses 1 kg, 2 kg, and 3 kg are at positions (0,0), (1,0), and (0,1) m. The y-coordinate of COM is:
questions.explanation_incorrect: y_cm = Σmᵢyᵢ/Σmᵢ = (0+0+3)/6 = 0.5 m.

questions.question_text: The centre of mass of a uniform ring lies at:

options.text: At the centre of the ring

questions.explanation_correct: Due to symmetry, the COM of a uniform ring is at its geometric centre, which is actually empty space.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The COM doesn't have to be inside the material. For a ring, it's at the centre of the ring.

questions.question_text: Torque is defined as:
questions.explanation_correct: Torque τ = r × F (vector cross product of position vector and force).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Torque is the cross product r × F, not the dot product. Its magnitude is rF sin θ.

questions.question_text: The SI unit of torque is:
questions.explanation_correct: Torque = force × distance = N·m. Although dimensionally same as joule, torque is measured in N·m.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Torque has units of newton-metre (N·m).

questions.question_text: A force of 5 N acts at the end of a spanner 0.4 m long, perpendicular to it. The torque is:
questions.explanation_incorrect: τ = rF = 0.4 × 5 = 2 N·m (since force is perpendicular).

questions.question_text: Angular momentum L is related to moment of inertia I and angular velocity ω by:
questions.explanation_correct: L = Iω is the rotational analogue of p = mv.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Angular momentum = moment of inertia × angular velocity. L = Iω.

questions.question_text: If no external torque acts on a system, the angular momentum is:
questions.explanation_correct: τ = dL/dt. If τ = 0, then dL/dt = 0 and L is constant. This is conservation of angular momentum.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Conservation of angular momentum: L = Iω = constant when net external torque is zero.

questions.question_text: A ballet dancer spins faster when she folds her arms because:

options.text: Her moment of inertia decreases, so ω increases (L = Iω = const)

questions.explanation_correct: Folding arms reduces I. Since L is conserved (no external torque), ω increases to keep Iω constant.
questions.explanation_incorrect: L = Iω = constant. Reducing I (folding arms) means ω must increase.

questions.question_text: The rotational analogue of Newton's second law is:
questions.explanation_correct: Just as F = ma for linear motion, τ = Iα for rotational motion (τ = torque, I = moment of inertia, α = angular acceleration).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The rotational second law: net torque = moment of inertia × angular acceleration.

questions.question_text: A disc of moment of inertia 2 kg·m² has angular velocity 10 rad/s. The torque needed to stop it in 5 s is:
questions.explanation_correct: α = Δω/Δt = 10/5 = 2 rad/s². τ = Iα = 2 × 2 = 4 N·m.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Angular deceleration α = 10/5 = 2 rad/s². τ = Iα = 2 × 2 = 4 N·m.

questions.question_text: The SI unit of angular momentum is:
questions.explanation_correct: L = Iω has units kg·m² × rad/s = kg·m²/s (also equivalent to J·s).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Angular momentum has SI unit kg·m²/s.

questions.question_text: The angular momentum of a particle of mass 2 kg moving with velocity 3 m/s at a perpendicular distance of 4 m from the axis is:
questions.explanation_correct: L = mvr = 2 × 3 × 4 = 24 kg·m²/s (r is the perpendicular distance).

questions.question_text: The moment of inertia of a ring of mass M and radius R about an axis through its centre and perpendicular to its plane is:
questions.explanation_correct: For a ring, all mass is at distance R from the axis, so I = MR².
questions.explanation_incorrect: All mass of a ring is at the same distance R from the central axis, giving I = MR².

questions.question_text: The moment of inertia of a uniform disc about an axis through its centre perpendicular to its plane is:
questions.explanation_correct: For a uniform disc, I = MR²/2 about the central perpendicular axis.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A disc has mass distributed from 0 to R, giving I = MR²/2 (half that of a ring).

questions.question_text: The moment of inertia of a solid sphere about its diameter is:
questions.explanation_correct: For a solid sphere about a diameter, I = 2MR²/5.
questions.explanation_incorrect: I = 2MR²/5 for solid sphere. 2MR²/3 is for a hollow sphere.

questions.question_text: The radius of gyration of a disc about its central axis is:
questions.explanation_correct: I = Mk² = MR²/2. So k² = R²/2, k = R/√2.
questions.explanation_incorrect: From I = Mk²: k = √(I/M) = √(R²/2) = R/√2.

questions.question_text: The rotational kinetic energy of a body is given by:
questions.explanation_correct: Rotational KE = ½Iω², analogous to ½mv² for translational KE.
questions.explanation_incorrect: KE_rot = ½Iω² (half × moment of inertia × angular velocity squared).

questions.question_text: A uniform rod of mass 6 kg and length 2 m has moment of inertia about its centre equal to:
questions.explanation_incorrect: For a rod about its centre: I = ML²/12 = 6 × 4/12 = 2 kg·m².

questions.question_text: The moment of inertia depends on:

options.text: Mass distribution and axis of rotation

questions.explanation_correct: I depends on the mass of the body, how that mass is distributed, and the axis about which rotation occurs.
questions.explanation_incorrect: I = Σmᵢrᵢ² depends on both the masses and their distances from the axis.

questions.question_text: The radius of gyration of a solid sphere about its diameter is:
questions.explanation_correct: I = 2MR²/5 = Mk². So k = R√(2/5).

questions.question_text: The moment of inertia of a hollow sphere about its diameter is:
questions.explanation_correct: For a thin hollow sphere (spherical shell), I = 2MR²/3 about a diameter.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Hollow sphere: I = 2MR²/3. Solid sphere: I = 2MR²/5.

questions.question_text: Moment of inertia is the rotational analogue of:
questions.explanation_correct: Just as mass resists change in linear motion, moment of inertia resists change in rotational motion.
questions.explanation_incorrect: I is the rotational analogue of m. τ is analogue of F. L is analogue of p.

questions.question_text: The parallel axis theorem states:
questions.explanation_correct: The parallel axis theorem: I = I_cm + Md², where d is the distance between the parallel axes.
questions.explanation_incorrect: I about any axis = I about parallel COM axis + Md². The moment always increases.

questions.question_text: The perpendicular axis theorem is applicable to:
questions.explanation_correct: The perpendicular axis theorem (I_z = I_x + I_y) applies only to planar (2D) bodies like rings, discs, and plates.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This theorem works only for flat, planar bodies. For 3D bodies, use the parallel axis theorem.

questions.question_text: The moment of inertia of a ring of mass M and radius R about a tangent in its plane is:
questions.explanation_correct: I_diameter = MR²/2 (perpendicular axis theorem: I_z = 2I_d, so I_d = MR²/2). By parallel axis: I_tangent = MR²/2 + MR² = 3MR²/2.
questions.explanation_incorrect: I about diameter = MR²/2. By parallel axis theorem: I_tangent = MR²/2 + MR² = 3MR²/2.

questions.question_text: The moment of inertia of a disc about a tangent perpendicular to its plane is:
questions.explanation_correct: I_centre = MR²/2. By parallel axis: I_tangent = MR²/2 + MR² = 3MR²/2.
questions.explanation_incorrect: By parallel axis theorem: I = I_cm + Md² = MR²/2 + MR² = 3MR²/2.

questions.question_text: The moment of inertia of a uniform rod about one end is:
questions.explanation_correct: I_centre = ML²/12. By parallel axis: I_end = ML²/12 + M(L/2)² = ML²/12 + ML²/4 = ML²/3.
questions.explanation_incorrect: I_end = I_centre + M(L/2)² = ML²/12 + ML²/4 = (ML² + 3ML²)/12 = ML²/3.

questions.question_text: For a ring, I about a diameter is:
questions.explanation_correct: By perpendicular axis theorem: I_z = I_x + I_y. By symmetry I_x = I_y. MR² = 2I_d. I_d = MR²/2.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Perpendicular axis theorem: MR² = I_d + I_d = 2I_d. So I_diameter = MR²/2.

questions.question_text: The moment of inertia of a disc about a diameter is:
questions.explanation_correct: By perpendicular axis theorem: I_z = I_x + I_y. MR²/2 = 2I_d. I_d = MR²/4.
questions.explanation_incorrect: MR²/2 = I_d + I_d (by symmetry). So I_diameter = MR²/4.

questions.question_text: The moment of inertia of a solid sphere about a tangent is:
questions.explanation_correct: I_tangent = I_diameter + MR² = 2MR²/5 + MR² = 7MR²/5.
questions.explanation_incorrect: By parallel axis theorem: I = 2MR²/5 + MR² = (2MR² + 5MR²)/5 = 7MR²/5.

questions.question_text: The parallel axis theorem always gives a moment of inertia that is:
questions.explanation_correct: Since I = I_cm + Md² and Md² > 0, the moment of inertia about any other parallel axis is always greater than about the COM axis.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Md² is always positive, so I about any shifted axis > I_cm. The COM axis gives the minimum I.

questions.question_text: The perpendicular axis theorem states I_z =
questions.explanation_correct: For a planar body in the xy-plane: I_z = I_x + I_y, where z is perpendicular to the plane.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The perpendicular axis theorem: I_z = I_x + I_y for laminar (flat) bodies.

questions.question_text: The condition for pure rolling (without slipping) is:
questions.explanation_correct: For pure rolling, the velocity of the centre of mass v_cm = Rω. The contact point has zero velocity.
questions.explanation_incorrect: In pure rolling, v = Rω. This ensures the contact point is instantaneously at rest.

questions.question_text: The total kinetic energy of a rolling body is:
questions.explanation_correct: KE_total = KE_translational + KE_rotational = ½mv² + ½Iω².
questions.explanation_incorrect: Rolling involves both translation and rotation, so total KE = ½mv² + ½Iω².

questions.question_text: A disc rolls down an incline of angle θ. Its acceleration is:
questions.explanation_correct: a = g sin θ/(1 + k²/R²). For disc, k²/R² = 1/2. a = g sin θ/(1 + 1/2) = g sin θ/(3/2) = 2g sin θ/3.
questions.explanation_incorrect: For a disc (I = MR²/2): a = g sin θ/(1 + 1/2) = 2g sin θ/3.

questions.question_text: A ring rolls down an incline. Its acceleration is:
questions.explanation_correct: For ring, k²/R² = 1. a = g sin θ/(1 + 1) = g sin θ/2.
questions.explanation_incorrect: For a ring (I = MR²): a = g sin θ/(1 + 1) = g sin θ/2.

questions.question_text: Among ring, disc, and solid sphere of same mass and radius rolling down the same incline, which reaches the bottom first?
questions.explanation_correct: Acceleration a = g sin θ/(1 + k²/R²). The solid sphere has the smallest k²/R² = 2/5, giving the largest acceleration.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sphere (k²/R² = 2/5) > disc (1/2) > ring (1). Smallest k²/R² = highest acceleration, so sphere wins.

questions.question_text: The ratio of translational to rotational KE for a rolling disc is:
questions.explanation_correct: KE_trans/KE_rot = (½mv²)/(½Iω²) = (½mv²)/(½ × MR²/2 × v²/R²) = (½mv²)/(mv²/4) = 2:1.
questions.explanation_incorrect: For disc: KE_rot = ½(MR²/2)(v/R)² = Mv²/4. KE_trans = Mv²/2. Ratio = 2:1.

questions.question_text: A solid sphere rolls without slipping down an incline of height h. Its speed at the bottom is:
questions.explanation_correct: mgh = ½mv²(1 + k²/R²) = ½mv²(1 + 2/5) = ½mv²(7/5). v = √(10gh/7).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Energy conservation: mgh = ½mv²(7/5). v² = 10gh/7. v = √(10gh/7).

questions.question_text: In pure rolling, the velocity of the topmost point of the body is:
questions.explanation_correct: The topmost point has translational velocity v (of COM) + rotational velocity Rω = v. Total = 2v.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Top point velocity = v_cm + Rω = v + v = 2v (both in same direction).

questions.question_text: In pure rolling, the velocity of the contact point with the ground is:
questions.explanation_correct: At the contact point, translational velocity v forward and rotational velocity Rω = v backward cancel out, giving zero.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Contact point: v_cm − Rω = v − v = 0. This is the condition for pure rolling.

questions.question_text: A cylinder of mass M rolls without slipping. The fraction of its total KE that is rotational is:
questions.explanation_correct: KE_rot = Mv²/4. KE_total = Mv²/2 + Mv²/4 = 3Mv²/4. Fraction = (Mv²/4)/(3Mv²/4) = 1/3.
questions.explanation_incorrect: For cylinder: KE_rot/KE_total = (½ × MR²/2 × ω²)/(½mv² + ½ × MR²/2 × ω²) = 1/3.

questions.question_text: How does the centre of mass of a uniform semicircular wire differ from that of a uniform semicircular disc, both of radius R?

options.text: Both are at the same distance from the centre
Semicircular wire: 2R/π from centre; semicircular disc: 4R/(3π) from centre — the wire's COM is farther
Semicircular disc's COM is farther than the wire's
Both lie at R/2 from the centre

questions.explanation_correct: For a semicircular wire, y_cm = 2R/π. For a semicircular disc, y_cm = 4R/(3π). Since 2R/π > 4R/(3π) (as 2/π ≈ 0.637 > 4/(3π) ≈ 0.424), the wire's COM is farther from the centre.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The wire has all mass concentrated on the arc (farther from centre on average), while the disc has mass distributed from 0 to R. So the wire's COM is farther.

questions.question_text: How does the moment of inertia of a solid sphere about its diameter differ from that of a hollow sphere of the same mass and radius?

options.text: Solid sphere has smaller I (2MR²/5 < 2MR²/3) because its mass is distributed closer to the axis
Hollow sphere has smaller I because it is lighter

questions.explanation_correct: Solid sphere: I = 2MR²/5. Hollow sphere: I = 2MR²/3. Since 2/5 < 2/3, the solid sphere has a smaller moment of inertia. This is because the solid sphere's mass is distributed throughout its volume (closer to the axis on average), while the hollow sphere has all mass at the maximum distance R.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Both have the same mass M and radius R. The difference is mass distribution: a solid sphere has more mass near the centre, reducing I. A hollow sphere has all mass on the surface at distance R, increasing I.

questions.question_text: How does the speed at the bottom of an incline differ between a ring and a solid sphere of the same mass and radius rolling without slipping from the same height h?

options.text: Ring is faster because it has higher moment of inertia
Solid sphere is faster: v_sphere = √(10gh/7), v_ring = √(gh)
Solid sphere is slower because it is heavier

questions.explanation_correct: For rolling, v = √(2gh/(1 + k²/R²)). Solid sphere: k²/R² = 2/5, so v = √(10gh/7). Ring: k²/R² = 1, so v = √(gh). Since 10/7 > 1, the sphere is faster. A smaller k²/R² means less energy goes to rotation, leaving more for translation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Speed depends on k²/R². The sphere (2/5) diverts less energy to rotation than the ring (1), so the sphere arrives faster.

questions.question_text: How does the parallel axis theorem differ from the perpendicular axis theorem in terms of applicability?

options.text: Parallel axis theorem applies to any rigid body; perpendicular axis theorem applies only to planar (2D) bodies
Parallel axis theorem applies only to planar bodies; perpendicular axis theorem applies to all

questions.explanation_correct: The parallel axis theorem (I = I_cm + Md²) works for any rigid body in any dimension. The perpendicular axis theorem (I_z = I_x + I_y) is valid only for flat, planar (laminar) bodies lying in the xy-plane.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The parallel axis theorem has no restriction on body shape. The perpendicular axis theorem requires the body to be a 2D lamina. You can use the parallel axis theorem on spheres, rods, etc.

questions.question_text: How does the angular momentum of a particle moving in a straight line differ from that of a particle moving in a circle, both about the same point?

options.text: Angular momentum exists only for circular motion, not for straight-line motion
Both have angular momentum about a point; for straight-line motion L = mvr⊥ (constant if no external torque), for circular motion L = mvR = Iω
Angular momentum is always zero for straight-line motion
Circular motion has zero angular momentum because the particle returns to the same point

questions.explanation_correct: Angular momentum L = r × p exists for any motion about any point. For a particle in a straight line, L = mvr⊥ (where r⊥ is the perpendicular distance from the line to the point) and remains constant if no torque acts. For circular motion, L = mvR = Iω.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Angular momentum is defined for any motion, not just circular. A particle in a straight line has constant angular momentum about any point (as long as no external torque acts), because the perpendicular distance from the point to the line of motion stays constant.

questions.question_text: A body has moment of inertia I = MR² about an axis through its centre perpendicular to its plane. All its mass is at the same distance R from the axis. This body is a:
questions.explanation_correct: Only a thin ring (or thin-walled hollow cylinder) has all mass at the same distance R from the axis, giving I = MR². A disc has I = MR²/2, a solid sphere has I = 2MR²/5.
questions.explanation_incorrect: I = MR² means every mass element is at distance R. Only a thin ring satisfies this. Disc and sphere have mass distributed at various distances, giving smaller I values.

questions.question_text: A system of particles has its centre of mass located outside the physical body. The total mass is concentrated on a curved surface. This system is most likely a:
questions.explanation_correct: A uniform ring has its COM at the geometric centre, which lies in empty space (not on the material of the ring). Additionally, all mass is on a curved surface (the circumference). Solid sphere, disc, and cube have their COM inside the material.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The COM of a ring lies at its centre, which is empty space — not on the ring material. This is a classic example of COM lying outside the body.

questions.question_text: A body moves on a surface with its bottom point instantaneously at rest and its topmost point moving at 2v. The body is undergoing:
questions.explanation_correct: In pure rolling (without slipping), the contact point has zero velocity (v_cm − Rω = 0) and the topmost point has velocity 2v_cm. These conditions define rolling without slipping: v = Rω.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Pure translation would give all points the same velocity. Pure rotation about the centre would give the contact point velocity v (not zero). Only rolling without slipping gives zero at bottom and 2v at top.

questions.question_text: A quantity is vector, has SI unit kg·m²/s, is conserved when net external torque is zero, and equals Iω. This quantity is:
questions.explanation_correct: Angular momentum L = Iω has units kg·m²/s, is a vector (axial), and is conserved when net external torque is zero (τ = dL/dt = 0 implies L = constant). All clues point to angular momentum.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Torque has units N·m. Moment of inertia has units kg·m² and is a scalar. Linear momentum has units kg·m/s. Only angular momentum matches all the given properties.

questions.question_text: Riya and Amit sit on opposite ends of a 4 m long uniform seesaw of negligible mass. Riya (30 kg) sits at one end and Amit (40 kg) at the other. The distance of the centre of mass from Riya's end is:
questions.explanation_correct: x_cm = (m₁x₁ + m₂x₂)/(m₁ + m₂) = (30×0 + 40×4)/(30+40) = 160/70 ≈ 2.29 m from Riya's end. The COM is closer to the heavier person (Amit).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The COM is at (30×0 + 40×4)/70 = 160/70 ≈ 2.3 m from Riya. It is not at the midpoint (2 m) because the masses are unequal.

questions.question_text: Priya, performing a physics experiment in the school lab, applies a force of 8 N at the end of a 0.5 m spanner at 30° to the spanner handle. The torque she produces about the bolt is:
questions.explanation_correct: τ = rF sin θ = 0.5 × 8 × sin 30° = 0.5 × 8 × 0.5 = 2 N·m. Only the perpendicular component of force (F sin θ) contributes to torque.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Torque = rF sin θ. The angle between the force and the lever arm is 30°. τ = 0.5 × 8 × 0.5 = 2 N·m.

questions.question_text: Arjun rolls a solid sphere (mass 2 kg, radius 0.1 m) and a ring (mass 2 kg, radius 0.1 m) down a 5 m high incline in the school lab. The difference in their speeds at the bottom is (g = 10 m/s²):

options.text: Sphere: √(500/7) ≈ 8.45 m/s; Ring: √50 ≈ 7.07 m/s; difference ≈ 1.38 m/s
Both arrive at the same speed
Sphere: 10 m/s; Ring: 5 m/s; difference = 5 m/s

questions.explanation_correct: Sphere: v = √(10gh/7) = √(10×10×5/7) = √(500/7) ≈ 8.45 m/s. Ring: v = √(gh) = √(10×5) = √50 ≈ 7.07 m/s. Difference ≈ 1.38 m/s. The sphere is faster because it has a smaller k²/R².
questions.explanation_incorrect: Speed at the bottom depends on k²/R², not on mass or radius directly. Sphere (k²/R² = 2/5) is faster than ring (k²/R² = 1). Mass cancels out in the energy equation.

questions.question_text: Meera is designing a flywheel for a physics project. She has a solid disc of mass 5 kg and radius 0.2 m. She needs to know its moment of inertia about an axis at the edge of the disc, perpendicular to its plane. The value is:
questions.explanation_correct: I_centre = ½MR² = ½ × 5 × 0.04 = 0.1 kg·m². By parallel axis theorem: I_edge = I_centre + MR² = 0.1 + 5 × 0.04 = 0.1 + 0.2 = 0.3 kg·m².
questions.explanation_incorrect: By the parallel axis theorem: I = I_cm + Md² = MR²/2 + MR² = 3MR²/2 = 3 × 5 × 0.04/2 = 0.3 kg·m².

questions.question_text: Rohan observes a spinning top (solid cone) in a toy shop. The top has I = 0.002 kg·m² and spins at 60 rad/s. When the tip friction slows it down, it takes 30 s to stop. The average frictional torque is:
questions.explanation_correct: α = Δω/Δt = 60/30 = 2 rad/s². τ = Iα = 0.002 × 2 = 0.004 N·m. This is the average retarding torque due to friction at the tip.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The angular deceleration is α = 60/30 = 2 rad/s². Torque = Iα = 0.002 × 2 = 0.004 N·m.

questions.question_text: The perpendicular axis theorem states I_z = I_x + I_y for planar bodies. Which of the following bodies cannot use this theorem?
questions.explanation_correct: The perpendicular axis theorem is valid only for planar (2D/laminar) bodies. A solid sphere is a 3D body with mass distributed in all three dimensions, so the perpendicular axis theorem cannot be applied to it.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ring, disc, and rectangular plate are all flat, planar bodies that lie in a single plane. The perpendicular axis theorem works for them. A solid sphere has mass in three dimensions and is not a lamina.

questions.question_text: Which of the following uniform bodies has its centre of mass NOT at a point where there is material?
questions.explanation_correct: A uniform ring has its COM at the geometric centre, which is empty space. Students often assume the COM must be inside the body's material, but a ring is the classic counterexample. Solid sphere, rod, and cube all have their COM at a point within the material.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The COM of a solid sphere, rod, and cube all lie inside the material. The ring's COM is at the centre of the ring, which has no material — it is in empty space.

questions.question_text: A body sliding down a frictionless incline does NOT roll. Which of the following seems like it should roll but actually slides without rolling on a frictionless surface?

options.text: A solid sphere on a rough incline
A cylinder on a rough surface
A solid sphere on a perfectly frictionless incline
A ring on a rough surface

questions.explanation_correct: A sphere looks like a rolling object, but on a perfectly frictionless incline, there is no tangential force to create torque about the COM. Without torque, no angular acceleration occurs, so the sphere slides without rotating. Friction is essential for rolling.
questions.explanation_incorrect: On a rough surface (A, B, D), friction provides the torque needed for rolling. On a frictionless surface, even a sphere will simply slide, because gravity through the COM produces zero torque about the COM.

questions.question_text: Why does a ballet dancer spin faster when she pulls her arms inward?

options.text: Because pulling arms inward increases her angular momentum
Because pulling arms inward reduces her moment of inertia, and since angular momentum (Iω) is conserved (no external torque), ω must increase
Because the external torque from her feet increases her speed
Because her mass decreases when she folds her arms

questions.explanation_correct: With no external torque, L = Iω is conserved. Pulling arms in reduces I (mass moves closer to axis). To keep L constant, ω must increase proportionally. This is conservation of angular momentum in action.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Her mass doesn't change. Angular momentum doesn't increase (it's conserved). There is no significant external torque. The reason is purely the conservation of angular momentum: smaller I requires larger ω.

questions.question_text: Why is the moment of inertia about the centre of mass axis always the minimum among all parallel axes?

options.text: Because the COM axis is always the longest
Because the parallel axis theorem adds a positive term Md² to I_cm, so any shifted axis has I > I_cm
Because the COM is always at the geometric centre
Because the body's density is maximum at the COM

questions.explanation_correct: The parallel axis theorem states I = I_cm + Md². Since M > 0 and d² > 0 (for any axis not through COM), the term Md² is always positive. Therefore I > I_cm for any parallel axis displaced by d from the COM axis.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The COM is not always at the geometric centre (non-uniform bodies). The reason is purely mathematical: the Md² term in the parallel axis theorem is always positive, making I_cm the minimum.

questions.question_text: Why does a solid sphere reach the bottom of an incline faster than a hollow sphere when both roll without slipping?

options.text: Because the solid sphere is heavier
Because the solid sphere has a smaller k²/R² (2/5 vs 2/3), so a smaller fraction of its energy goes to rotation, leaving more for translation and giving a larger acceleration
Because the solid sphere has less friction
Because the hollow sphere has more air resistance

questions.explanation_correct: Rolling acceleration a = g sin θ/(1 + k²/R²). Solid sphere has k²/R² = 2/5, giving a = 5g sin θ/7. Hollow sphere has k²/R² = 2/3, giving a = 3g sin θ/5. Since 5/7 > 3/5, the solid sphere accelerates faster. This is because a smaller k²/R² means less energy is diverted to rotation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Mass and radius cancel in the rolling acceleration formula. The key factor is k²/R², which determines the fraction of gravitational PE converted to rotational KE vs translational KE. Smaller k²/R² = faster rolling.
